title: Water Weather Station | IoT System
description: Scaling API infrastructure and optimizing database
caseStudy:
Overview

The Water Weather Station project is a real-time IoT system designed to collect and monitor water quality and weather conditions across remote locations. This system was developed to support field research and data analysis, ultimately improving environmental monitoring and infrastructure planning.

My Role

I led the frontend development and contributed to backend architecture. I built a responsive web interface to visualize sensor data in real time, integrated a scalable API layer to handle high-frequency data ingestion, and optimized database queries to support performance across large datasets.

Challenges

One of the key challenges was optimizing data flow between sensors and the dashboard while ensuring reliable real-time updates without overwhelming the server. We addressed this by implementing message queuing, aggressive caching, and efficient WebSocket communication.

Impact

The system is actively used in Navy-funded field deployments and helps researchers and engineers collect and interpret water/weather metrics with increased accuracy. It has enhanced responsiveness to environmental changes and provides a scalable foundation for future sensor expansion.

Takeaways

This project deepened my experience with real-time systems and highlighted the importance of designing for data efficiency and resilience in resource-constrained environments. It also reinforced the power of thoughtful UI/UX in communicating technical data clearly.

title: The Lucky Effect | Website and eCommerce Store
caseStudy:
Overview

The Lucky Effect needed a professional digital presence that could grow with them while remaining easy to maintain without a full scale technical team. They wanted to promote music, tours, and social links from one centralized site without constant manual updates.

This was a solo freelance project built from scratch. I worked directly with the band, balancing their creative vision with performance and scalability needs, while keeping within a small budget and tight turnaround time.

Approach

I started by creating low-fidelity mockups to outline key content sections: music, video, events, and social links. Once approved, I:

  • Chose Next.js for static generation and easy routing
  • Used Tailwind CSS for rapid styling
  • Hosted on Vercel with custom domain setup
  • Built out both a public site and a hidden preview environment for stealth updates

Challenges

One of the key challenges was needing to manual update the website for every new release. I addressed this by using embedded links and APIs to platforms (Spotify, YouTube, Bandsintown) to automate content refresh without editing code.

Another challenge was the risk of breaking the live site during updates and getting pre-approval from all teammembers. To combat this I created a hidden, password-protected preview version of the site for internal review and testing.

Impact

  • Delivered a fast, lightweight site tailored to the band's style and needs
  • Enabled real-time content updates through integrations with streaming platforms
  • Provided a cost-effective, low-maintenance solution the band could own and grow with
  • Positive feedback from the band and their fans

Takeaways

This project deepened my confidence in creating full-stack solo solutions. I learned how to set up low-cost yet powerful infrastructure, and how to integrate dynamic third-party tools without bloating the codebase. In the future, I'd consider layering in a headless CMS if content demands grow.
